post_text: August 28, 2016 at 2:24 AM#1I've looked a bit on the forums and have found various ways to accomplish some of what I want, but not all of what I want. Here's what I'm wanting to do:Write a macro that will store a cue and then label that cue with a predefined name (i.e. Verse, Chorus, Bridge, etc).I've got macros that will store the cue, go to the cue, and then run the Label command. Then I have to type the name. I'm trying to eliminate typing the name itself, but if I put anything after the "Label" command, it tries to find a cue labeled that name.Anyone know how to do this? I'm just wanting several different macros that I can push "Store Verse" "Store Chorus" "Store Bridge" etc etc.Bonus points if I could have a single macro that I can push and then type in a number. 1=Verse 2=Chorus 3=Bridge, etc.-Tyler

posts.author: thetylerherron
posts.post_text: August 28, 2016 at 9:03 AM#3That's exactly what I'm looking for! Thank you sir!Here's the macro I came up with if someone else wants to use or modify. I added a little option to type in something other than a number. So if one of the 6 options isn't what you wanted the name to be, you can just type in the name and the macro will take care of it.Code01: Store02: Go03: SetUserVar $section = ("1=Verse, 2=Chorus, 3=Bridge, 4=Inst, 5=Build, 6=Ending")04: SetUserVar $otherBool = "true"05: [$section == 1]  SetUserVar $cuename = "Verse";  SetUserVar $otherBool = "false"06: [$section == 2]  SetUserVar $cuename = "Chorus";  SetUserVar $otherBool = "false"07: [$section == 3]  SetUserVar $cuename = "Bridge";  SetUserVar $otherBool = "false"08: [$section == 4]  SetUserVar $cuename = "Instrumental";  SetUserVar $otherBool = "false"09: [$section == 5]  SetUserVar $cuename = "Build";  SetUserVar $otherBool = "false"10: [$section == 6]  SetUserVar $cuename = "Ending";  SetUserVar $otherBool = "false"11: [$otherBool == true]  SetUserVar $cuename = $section12: Label Cue $selectedexeccue $"cuename"Display More

posts.post_text: October 30, 2016 at 10:18 AM#7The other bool variable was so I could type in a different name if I didn't want to use one of the "pre-defined" names I had set. As Ryan suggested there was a more efficient way of doing that, though.In practice, this macro hasn't been super useful. I don't use this macro to store cues and label them, as I've found it faster to just write 6 different macros for each. One push of a button gets me the result, instead of 3 (Macro, type number, please). If I used a lot of macros, I could probably consolidate it back, but right now I have room, so I just use a bunch for each situation.

posts.author: thetylerherron
posts.post_text: October 30, 2016 at 10:23 AM#8Code01: Store02: Go Fade 003: Label Cue $selectedexeccue ("Name?")04: Assign Cue $selectedexeccue /cmd=("CMD?")That should work for you. I think. Not at a console to test. fyi, I like to add the "fade 0" to this kind of macro so I don't have to wait for the cue to finish transitioning to name it. The macro gives me some trouble if I don't.
